Hi,
	That got your attention?

	I'm starting to look at putting speciation into SLEAT.  And I'm wondering 
exactly how to approach it.

	Let me summarize NEAT-style speciation, then it will be easier to point 
out where my situation diverges.

--

Species are each defined by an exemplar.  This is an individual chosen for 
use in comparisons.  Any individual within some threshold similarity to the 
exemplar is potentially member of the species.

Individuals are assigned to the first species that they match and remain in 
the species.  Some implementations allow for periodic regeneration of species.

Because traditional NEAT is generational, exemplars are drawn from the 
previous generation (is this right, I think the original paper is vague on 
this and I know it because it was discussed here previously, but I forget 
the details).  Each exemplar is one random (fittest?) member drawn from 
each species in the previous generation.

Any new individual that fits no species becomes the exemplar (and 
presumably first member) of a new species.

Any exemplar that matches no individuals from the new generation represents 
a species going extinct.

The purpose of speciation is to assign offspring between groups of 
individuals in a manner other than their simple proportion in the 
population.  Offspring are assigned to species based on the "adjusted 
fitness" which is the maximum fitness seen in the species, divided by the 
number of members it has.  Offspring are assigned to each species according 
to the proportions of their adjusted finesses (in chemical/physical speak, 
it's a partition function).

--

	OK, now where I differ is my system is continuous, I create one new 
individual at a time, present it to the population, and somebody dies as a 
result.

	Now no part of the standard evolution scheme is incompatible with this, I 
can pick individuals from species probabilistically, according to the 
adjusted fitness of the species.  I can introduce individuals one at a time 
and assign then to species.  I can spawn new species when an individual is 
too different from any existing species...

	But the one question that is not answered is: Who dies?

	At present I kill the least-fit member of the population.  But what is 
suited when their are species.  I see three plans:

1) kill the population loser
2) kill the species loser in the species getting the offspring
3) kill the species loser in a random species
4) (FOUR plans, I said FOUR) kill a completely random individual

	What do people think?  Ken, I'm particularly interested in your take on 
this because you must have just done something similar for NERO...?

	Ian
